Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports research in gravitational wave detector instrumentation and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. This award sponsors the development of novel compact seismic sensing technologies that provide highly sensitive observations of slow seismic phenomena on platforms under extreme conditions such as low pressures (vacuum) and low temperatures (cryogenics). In this project, parameters of sensitivity and bandwidth will be studied to develop optomechanical seismic sensors that are compatible with and can be installed in future gravitational wave observatories, such as LIGO Voyager. Seismic sensors are used to measure external disturbances acting on the platforms and provide signals than can be used to stabilize them. Moreover, the research conducted in this project will advance the development of technologies that enable further advancements relevant to other scientific and technological areas such as seismology, geodesy, precision measurements of vibrations, generally inertial sensing and inertial navigation, where highly compact form factors and high sensitivities can be advantageous. This award will support the participation of this research group in activities of the international LIGO Scientific Collaboration and the gravitational wave community at large; also providing for students to be trained in precision measurements and STEM areas, and helping to educate the local community in the new area of gravitational wave astronomy.<br/><br/>This project aims to develop highly compact monolithic optomechanical seismic sensors for ground-based gravitational wave observatories, such as LIGO, as an alternative to current solutions. LIGO currently uses commercial seismometers that are not readily compatible with vacuum or low temperature environments and are physically large - approximately 15 kg and 30 liters. Inertial sensors capable of operating in these conditions are required for future gravitational wave detectors, such as LIGO Voyager, and need to be developed, which is the goal of this project. In addition, the research plan envisions the development of an optomechanical seismic sensing instrument that will serve as a test platform to assess relevant sensor parameters to guide the technology development and help study their performance at low frequencies - from 10 mHz to slightly above 10 Hz. These results will outline the path for the development of cryogenic- and vacuum-compatible optomechanical seismic sensors for future generation gravitational wave observatories and will be relevant to many other STEM areas.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is the initiate the development of novel, small seismic sensors of very high sensitivity. These sensors are designed for use on gravitational-wave observatories, like the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO), as well as future similar facilities. Our technology is developed to be compatible with vacuum and cryogenic environments, which are features needed for the next generation of gravitational-wave observatories.

We have succeeded in developing a prototype sensor that is compact, light, and can operate with low power consumption. In our tests, we compared the performance of our prototype system to existing, commercial seismometer instruments and have thus demonstrated its capability of observing real ground motion signals.

Our sensor consists of microfabricated monolithic mechanical resonators that are integrated with highly sensitive laser interferometers to measure their response to external accelerations, such as seismic and gravitational signals.

Our optomechanical inertial sensing technologies can achieve high sensitivities, and thus can likely be used to enhance measurement systems that need to operate under extreme conditions such as cryogenic environments, high pressures, deep sea, underground, and even in space. They can also be used in a wide range of applications such as the measurement of acceleration, force, and vibrations, as well as helping with navigation, sensing earthquakes, and understanding gravity.

Throughout this project, our team has actively engaged in the education of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as in outreach activities involving high, middle, and elementary schools. With these efforts we aim to show our community what are the current scientific advances, and what is their impact; we want to explain what gravitational waves are, where they come from, and how the scientific community has been able to develop the technology to observe them over the past few decades. By doing this, we also show the younger population what are careers in STEM and show some of the possible paths to pursuing such a career.
